Filename: PROJECTS/1 Winner - Hanneke Van Camp/ 1 Winner-Hanneke Van Camp-1153_61092_3511.jpg
Name: Hanneke Van Camp
Bio: Ever since I first traveled to Sápmi, I’ve felt deeply connected to its landscapes and culture. It has become my part-time home - a place of incredible beauty but also of fragility, facing threats from climate change and exploitation. Through this project, I hope to share its unique diversity and invite others to reconnect with nature and the values it carries.
Title: Sápmi - Living Landscapes
Caption: Ever since I first traveled to Sápmi, I’ve felt deeply connected to its landscapes and culture. It has become my part-time home - a place of incredible beauty but also of fragility, facing threats from climate change and exploitation. Through this project, I hope to share its unique diversity and invite others to reconnect with nature and the values it carries.

Filename: SPECIALS/Rocks and Geology/3 Third Place-Torsten Pull-4071_61125_1704.jpg
Name: Torsten Pull
Bio: The image was taken on a Mesa in Utah on a freezing December morning (-10C/14F). Hiking up in the dark to this amazing place was an interested experience. The scene that unfolded before me was definetely worth the effort.
Title: Tumbling
Caption: The image was taken on a Mesa in Utah on a freezing December morning (-10C/14F). Hiking up in the dark to this amazing place was an interested experience. The scene that unfolded before me was definetely worth the effort.

Name: Lizzie Shepherd
Bio: Harris is perhaps best known for its pristine, sandy beaches, but I am always drawn to its extraordinary rocky shoreline, made up of Lewisian gneiss formed millions of years ago. The challenge is to marry that complex and beautiful foreground with the wonderful backdrop of the Harris Hills in the distance. This is the closest I've come yet, but it's work in progress!
Title: A shoreline of ancient Lewisian gneiss at dawn, with the Harris Hill beyond.
Caption: Harris is perhaps best known for its pristine, sandy beaches, but I am always drawn to its extraordinary rocky shoreline, made up of Lewisian gneiss formed millions of years ago. The challenge is to marry that complex and beautiful foreground with the wonderful backdrop of the Harris Hills in the distance. This is the closest I've come yet, but it's work in progress!

Filename: MAIN CATEGORIES/Intimate Landscape/4 Highly Commended-祐也 若松-6195_61003_5916.jpg
Name: Yuya Ｗakamatsu
Bio: Amidst a snowstorm in the Japanese mountains, this ancient tree stood veiled in frost and silence. I was drawn to its enduring presence, revealing a quiet strength within the winter mist.
Title: Frozen Silence
Caption: Amidst a snowstorm in the Japanese mountains, this ancient tree stood veiled in frost and silence. I was drawn to its enduring presence, revealing a quiet strength within the winter mist.

Name: Luis Vilariño
Bio: The wind accumulated the snow at the foot of the gigantic blocks of ice based on the shore. It stopped snowing, but the wind kept blowing hard, lifting and depositing volcanic sand on the snow, shading the relief and textures as a charcoal artist would have done.
Title: Ice & Wind
Caption: The wind accumulated the snow at the foot of the gigantic blocks of ice based on the shore. It stopped snowing, but the wind kept blowing hard, lifting and depositing volcanic sand on the snow, shading the relief and textures as a charcoal artist would have done.

Name: Dave Shaw
Bio: This type of woodland is quite tricky to photograph as it is so busy, and generally needs mist or thick fog to do it justice. For this particular trip I didn't have those conditions and decided to scout the area rather than focus on the photography. However, just as I was about to start the long trek back to the car, the sun came out and lit up this scene, leaving me scrambling to get 'something' before it disappared again. Chaotic by nature chaotic by capture!
Title: Jurassic World
Caption: This type of woodland is quite tricky to photograph as it is so busy, and generally needs mist or thick fog to do it justice. For this particular trip I didn't have those conditions and decided to scout the area rather than focus on the photography. However, just as I was about to start the long trek back to the car, the sun came out and lit up this scene, leaving me scrambling to get 'something' before it disappared again. Chaotic by nature chaotic by capture!

Filename: PROJECTS/3 Third Place - Theo Bosboom/3 Third Place-Theo Bosboom-532_59536_235.jpg
Name: Theo Bosboom
Bio: What would an ant see if it looked up while walking through a field of flowers? Flowerscapes is a wonderful and extraordinary photographic tribute to our wild flowers, captured from an insect’s perspective. Photographer Theo Bosboom used a special lens for this, embarking on an exploration of countless flower fields in his home country the Netherlands and sometimes just across the border in Germany or Belgium.
Title: Flowerscapes, A bug's eye view
Caption: What would an ant see if it looked up while walking through a field of flowers? Flowerscapes is a wonderful and extraordinary photographic tribute to our wild flowers, captured from an insect’s perspective. Photographer Theo Bosboom used a special lens for this, embarking on an exploration of countless flower fields in his home country the Netherlands and sometimes just across the border in Germany or Belgium.

Name: Vojtech Schmidt
Bio: At first, this didn’t feel like an obvious scene. But when the sun rose and golden light began to spill across the fresh snow, the whole scene came together. The halo effect caused by drifting snow was the cherry on top – a reward after a long, frigid night.
Title: Snow pit
Caption: At first, this didn’t feel like an obvious scene. But when the sun rose and golden light began to spill across the fresh snow, the whole scene came together. The halo effect caused by drifting snow was the cherry on top – a reward after a long, frigid night.

Filename: MAIN CATEGORIES/Intimate Landscape/2 Runner Up-Vojtech Schmidt-3116_61786_6113.jpg
Name: Vojtech Schmidt
Bio: During a winter expedition in the snowy expanses of Finnish Lapland, I was granted a fleeting encounter. With my camera ready, I managed to quietly capture a glimpse before the willow grouse disappeared into the white silence.
Title: Ptarmigan in the White Darkness
Caption: During a winter expedition in the snowy expanses of Finnish Lapland, I was granted a fleeting encounter. With my camera ready, I managed to quietly capture a glimpse before the willow grouse disappeared into the white silence.

Filename: PHOTOGRAPHER OF THE YEAR/5 Fifth Place - Vojtech Schmidt/5-Vojtech Schmidt-3116_61785_6113.jpg
Name: Vojtech Schmidt
Bio: I lost myself for hours photographing in a frosty gorge, surrounded by countless icicles. This one was my favourite — like nature’s chandelier, suspended above the stream.
Title: Icy Jewelry
Caption: I lost myself for hours photographing in a frosty gorge, surrounded by countless icicles. This one was my favourite — like nature’s chandelier, suspended above the stream.

Filename: PROJECTS/2 Runner Up - Feli Hansen/ 2 Runner Up-Feli Hansen-304_58977_403.jpg
Name: Feli Hansen
Bio: Plastic pollution is everywhere. Yet, somehow, remains unseen by many. But plastic pollution doesn’t just mar our landscapes; it poisons them. With this series I wanted to make the invisible visible again, so it cannot be longer ignored. We must act now, to preserve the beauty and vitality of our planet.
Title: Guilty Trashures
Caption: Plastic pollution is everywhere. Yet, somehow, remains unseen by many. But plastic pollution doesn’t just mar our landscapes; it poisons them. With this series I wanted to make the invisible visible again, so it cannot be longer ignored. We must act now, to preserve the beauty and vitality of our planet.

Name: Kenny Muir
Bio: A dead Scots pine tree can remain upright for many decades as its high resin content and dense heartwood provide resistance to decay. This photograph was captured in Scotland's ancient Caledonian Forest during an exceptionally cold start to winter. The backlit frost on the pine snag made it a striking presence against the frozen woodland beyond.
Title: Remnant of time
Caption: A dead Scots pine tree can remain upright for many decades as its high resin content and dense heartwood provide resistance to decay. This photograph was captured in Scotland's ancient Caledonian Forest during an exceptionally cold start to winter. The backlit frost on the pine snag made it a striking presence against the frozen woodland beyond.

Name: John Meragias
Bio: This black and white photo of Deadvlei was taken from an open door helicopter. The trees of Deadvlei are hundreds of years old and have also been dead for hundreds of years. They are now monuments to their own destruction and these two look like they will be together forever.
Title: Alone Together
Caption: This black and white photo of Deadvlei was taken from an open door helicopter. The trees of Deadvlei are hundreds of years old and have also been dead for hundreds of years. They are now monuments to their own destruction and these two look like they will be together forever.

Filename: MAIN CATEGORIES/Abstract Landscapes/2 Runner Up-Alex Pansier-7375_53123_5737.jpg
Name: Alex Pansier
Bio: Captured in April 2024 over Iceland’s frozen waters, this aerial view reveals drifting ice formations. Viewed from above, a rock, eerily resembling a face, appears trapped among other shards. This scene invites viewers to find beauty and meaning in nature’s abstract, ephemeral patterns.
Title: Trapped in Ice
Caption: Captured in April 2024 over Iceland’s frozen waters, this aerial view reveals drifting ice formations. Viewed from above, a rock, eerily resembling a face, appears trapped among other shards. This scene invites viewers to find beauty and meaning in nature’s abstract, ephemeral patterns.

Filename: MAIN CATEGORIES/Grand Landscape/3 Third Place-Gunar Streu-8202_53855_2028.jpg
Name: Gunar Streu
Bio: Blizzard along the coastline on Söröya Island in the most northern part of Norway. It became difficult to take photos because of the cold and stormy weather so I took only a few exposures. I tried to capture the harsh conditions you can find in Arctic regions.
Title: Snowy weather
Caption: Blizzard along the coastline on Söröya Island in the most northern part of Norway. It became difficult to take photos because of the cold and stormy weather so I took only a few exposures. I tried to capture the harsh conditions you can find in Arctic regions.

Filename: PROJECTS/5 Fifth Place - Joshua Wallace/ 5 Fifth Place-Joshua Wallace-9526_66283_6259.jpg
Name: Joshua Wallace
Bio: Reptiles and Amphibians are fantastic animals with breathtaking adaptations in order to call all of the diverse landscapes and habitats of our incredible planet home. However they live cryptic secretive lives hidden from all but the most curious eyes.
Title: Realms of Reptiles and Amphibians
Caption: Reptiles and Amphibians are fantastic animals with breathtaking adaptations in order to call all of the diverse landscapes and habitats of our incredible planet home. However they live cryptic secretive lives hidden from all but the most curious eyes.

Name: Spencer Cox
Bio: The enigmatic patterns of these marble caves struck me as telling a story of creation: growing trees, ancient mountains, swirling galaxies. After taking this photo, I learned that that the marble in this scene was only saved from mining because it is considered "low quality." I wonder, then, how many other remarkable scenes have vanished in service of our countertops?
Title: Creation of Earth
Caption: The enigmatic patterns of these marble caves struck me as telling a story of creation: growing trees, ancient mountains, swirling galaxies. After taking this photo, I learned that that the marble in this scene was only saved from mining because it is considered "low quality." I wonder, then, how many other remarkable scenes have vanished in service of our countertops?

Filename: 00 Photograph of the Year, Winner - Margrit Schwarz - 23656__3690__65632.jpg
Name: Margrit Schwarz
Award: (' Abstract and Details, Photograph of the Year, Winner',)
Bio: I made this photograph on the final morning of a twelve-day raft trip on the Colorado River. The Grand Canyon’s immensity was overwhelming, yet what captivated me most were the ancient layers of stone, shaped by time and water into abstract forms alive with mystery. For me, "Eye of the Canyon" remains an open invitation to explore, and to return - again and again.
Title: Eye of the Canyon
Caption: I made this photograph on the final morning of a twelve-day raft trip on the Colorado River. The Grand Canyon’s immensity was overwhelming, yet what captivated me most were the ancient layers of stone, shaped by time and water into abstract forms alive with mystery. For me, "Eye of the Canyon" remains an open invitation to explore, and to return - again and again.

Name: Robert Birkby
Bio: A photograph captured at the end of a summer's day on the Isle of Harris, Scotland. The light was fading and a long exposure time of two minutes was used to smooth the ocean and clouds, which seemed to complement each other perfectly.
Title: Curves
Caption: A photograph captured at the end of a summer's day on the Isle of Harris, Scotland. The light was fading and a long exposure time of two minutes was used to smooth the ocean and clouds, which seemed to complement each other perfectly.

Name: Ilan Shacham
Bio:
The Dead sea is a lake about 10 times more saline than the ocean. I am always fascinated by all the different types of salt formations, that have been created by various crystallization conditions.
In this photo we can sea "pearls" of salt, on a hardened bed of salt, with ridges of salt running randomly through the scene, all this side lit by the early morning sun.
Title: Salty Pearls
Caption:
The Dead sea is a lake about 10 times more saline than the ocean. I am always fascinated by all the different types of salt formations, that have been created by various crystallization conditions.
In this photo we can sea "pearls" of salt, on a hardened bed of salt, with ridges of salt running randomly through the scene, all this side lit by the early morning sun.

Filename: SPECIALS/In Your Backyard/2 Runner Up-Anton Gorlin-341_56761_143.jpg
Name: Anton Gorlin
Bio: I like finding the unusual in the mundane, whether it’s pareidolia or a sudden metaphor. In this case, it wasn’t just an old tree. The moment I saw it, I saw Jabba, slouching into the landscape like he'd always been there.
Title: Jabba the Hutt
Caption: I like finding the unusual in the mundane, whether it’s pareidolia or a sudden metaphor. In this case, it wasn’t just an old tree. The moment I saw it, I saw Jabba, slouching into the landscape like he'd always been there.

Name: Louis Ouimet
Bio: You usually don't go to sand dunes to get snow photos, but after heavy dump of snow at the Great Sand Dunes National Park that was unexpectedly what I was gifted!
Title: Unexpected
Caption: You usually don't go to sand dunes to get snow photos, but after heavy dump of snow at the Great Sand Dunes National Park that was unexpectedly what I was gifted!

Name: Patrick Krohn
Bio: The roots of this pine tree were exposed after it was toppled when Hurricane Helene hit South Carolina with wind gusts over 70 mph in late September 2024. Thousands of healthy trees were delimbed or uprooted, and cleanup efforts of the wreckage took months. Evident that this image was taken in January 2025, and this tree was finally removed in February – five months after the storm.
Title: Emerging From the Wreckage
Caption: The roots of this pine tree were exposed after it was toppled when Hurricane Helene hit South Carolina with wind gusts over 70 mph in late September 2024. Thousands of healthy trees were delimbed or uprooted, and cleanup efforts of the wreckage took months. Evident that this image was taken in January 2025, and this tree was finally removed in February – five months after the storm.

Filename: PHOTOGRAPHER OF THE YEAR/1 Winner - Joy Kachina/1-Joy Kachina-0634_60235_4360.jpg
Name: Joy Kachina
Bio: A blackwood tree native to the region is silhouetted by the rising sun in Meander Valley, Northern Tasmania. As sunlight touches the leaves, transpiration takes place.
Title: Transpiration
Caption: A blackwood tree native to the region is silhouetted by the rising sun in Meander Valley, Northern Tasmania. As sunlight touches the leaves, transpiration takes place.

Name: Prajit Ravindran
Bio: In January of this year, I had planned a trip to Bryce Canyon. There was no forecast of snow, but I hoped for fog instead and went anyway. On this freezing morning, I was greeted with snow flurries instead. As I was photographing this magical scene, I heard the words - "I guess we are the only crazy ones to be around here this morning" from the only other person I saw that morning, who happened to be a landscape photographer too.
Title: Snow Globe
Caption: In January of this year, I had planned a trip to Bryce Canyon. There was no forecast of snow, but I hoped for fog instead and went anyway. On this freezing morning, I was greeted with snow flurries instead. As I was photographing this magical scene, I heard the words - "I guess we are the only crazy ones to be around here this morning" from the only other person I saw that morning, who happened to be a landscape photographer too.

Filename: MAIN CATEGORIES/Abstract Landscapes/4 Highly Commended-Scott Oller-5731_64157_1375.jpg
Name: Scott Oller
Bio: I visited a towering waterfall, far off-trail up a seldom-visited gorge in Yosemite. Most of the waterfall was in shadow, but a ray of light met the mist in just the right place for a shimmering rainbow to appear. As I photographed it, the prismatic spray drifted from side to side in the wind.
Title: Illilouette Spirit, Yosemite National Park.
Caption: I visited a towering waterfall, far off-trail up a seldom-visited gorge in Yosemite. Most of the waterfall was in shadow, but a ray of light met the mist in just the right place for a shimmering rainbow to appear. As I photographed it, the prismatic spray drifted from side to side in the wind.

Name: Scott Oller
Bio: I love the thrill of watching the sunset from high on a remote mountain, knowing that a long descent in the dark awaits. This distant view of Cloud’s Rest, framed by a glowing ridgeline, caught my eye with its vibrant colors and angular lines.
Title: Last Light on Cloud’s Rest
Caption: I love the thrill of watching the sunset from high on a remote mountain, knowing that a long descent in the dark awaits. This distant view of Cloud’s Rest, framed by a glowing ridgeline, caught my eye with its vibrant colors and angular lines.

Filename: PHOTOGRAPHER OF THE YEAR/4 Fourth Place - Scott Oller/4-Scott Oller-5731_64156_1375.jpg
Name: Scott Oller
Bio: I love the challenge of finding unique perspectives in one of the most photographed places on earth: Yosemite National Park. My approach to landscape photography focuses on subject depth, rather than breadth. By returning again and again to the same beloved place, I continually discover new ways to express my personal vision of Yosemite.
Title: n/a - photographer of the year 4th place award
Caption: I love the challenge of finding unique perspectives in one of the most photographed places on earth: Yosemite National Park. My approach to landscape photography focuses on subject depth, rather than breadth. By returning again and again to the same beloved place, I continually discover new ways to express my personal vision of Yosemite.

Name: Pål Hermansen
Bio: The low winter light plays over the ice surface, revealing an otherwise unseen world. .
Title: Light play over the lake
Caption: The low winter light plays over the ice surface, revealing an otherwise unseen world. .

Filename: MAIN CATEGORIES/Abstract Landscapes/3 Third Place-Lukas Furlan-5185_54046_5815.jpg
Name: Lukas Furlan
Bio: Taken on an early morning in South Tyrol, this image captures the intricate patterns formed within a small mountain stream. Instead of looking up at the towering peaks, I became absorbed in the stream’s luminous structures—where flowing water, light, and color intertwined into abstract forms. What unfolded felt like a hidden landscape within the landscape, alive with movement and quiet intensity.
Title: Electric Currents
Caption: Taken on an early morning in South Tyrol, this image captures the intricate patterns formed within a small mountain stream. Instead of looking up at the towering peaks, I became absorbed in the stream’s luminous structures—where flowing water, light, and color intertwined into abstract forms. What unfolded felt like a hidden landscape within the landscape, alive with movement and quiet intensity.

Filename: MAIN CATEGORIES/Abstract Landscapes/4 Highly Commended-Lukas Furlan-5185_58601_5815.jpg
Name: Lukas Furlan
Bio: Taken along Spain’s rugged coastline during sunset, this photograph captures a striking rock face that seems to echo the sunset itself.
Title: Sunset Cliff
Caption: Taken along Spain’s rugged coastline during sunset, this photograph captures a striking rock face that seems to echo the sunset itself.

Filename: PROJECTS/4 Fourth Place - Lukas Furlan/ 4 Fourth Place-Lukas Furlan-5185_54032_5815.jpg
Name: Lukas Furlan
Bio: In winter’s muted forest, vibrant clusters of mistletoe stand out like otherworldly green orbs. The project captures their surreal beauty and resilient presence against the quiet desolation of the season.
Title: Among Bare Branches
Caption: In winter’s muted forest, vibrant clusters of mistletoe stand out like otherworldly green orbs. The project captures their surreal beauty and resilient presence against the quiet desolation of the season.

Name: Rupert Kogler
Bio: Areas where sun and fog merge are always worth a closer look, especially in the woods. This particular day I just went out to a forest close to my hometown and I was lucky enough to experience these conditions, but not enough of that, the sun was already very low and the light was warm. But the most mesmerizing thing actually was, that the sun melted the hoar frost in the tree tops and these particles of ice finally fell down as a glittering curtain from time to time.
Title: Heat of Hoar
Caption: Areas where sun and fog merge are always worth a closer look, especially in the woods. This particular day I just went out to a forest close to my hometown and I was lucky enough to experience these conditions, but not enough of that, the sun was already very low and the light was warm. But the most mesmerizing thing actually was, that the sun melted the hoar frost in the tree tops and these particles of ice finally fell down as a glittering curtain from time to time.

Filename: SPECIALS/In Your Backyard/3 Third Place-Jack Krohn-5391_65811_1935.jpg
Name: Jack Krohn
Bio: This image is from a memorable outing to a local park, where I often take our dog for exercise and enjoy exploring as the seasons change. During a cold snap in January, the shallow pond that forms during winter rains froze over, creating irresistible conditions we don't often see in the lowlands of Puget Sound, including this scene of leaves encased in ice. I felt that the reflections of the surrounding bushes and sky added interesting structure and an unexpected color palette, while the complex ice textures contributed a sense of impressionism to the image.
Title: Cling
Caption: This image is from a memorable outing to a local park, where I often take our dog for exercise and enjoy exploring as the seasons change. During a cold snap in January, the shallow pond that forms during winter rains froze over, creating irresistible conditions we don't often see in the lowlands of Puget Sound, including this scene of leaves encased in ice. I felt that the reflections of the surrounding bushes and sky added interesting structure and an unexpected color palette, while the complex ice textures contributed a sense of impressionism to the image.

Name: Ross Davidson
Bio: The view from 'The Fiddler' is arguably one of the greatest in Scotland, with the excellent vantage point of the spectacular, monolithic peaks that rise abruptly from the expansive landscape of Assynt and Coigach. The image was my attempt at creating an intricate, detailed and unique composition at what is a relative 'classic'  - as far as mountain photography in Scotland is concerned, at least! Hopefully, you agree that I have achieved that.
Title: Allure' - Sgurr an Fhidhleir, Coigach, Scotland
Caption: The view from 'The Fiddler' is arguably one of the greatest in Scotland, with the excellent vantage point of the spectacular, monolithic peaks that rise abruptly from the expansive landscape of Assynt and Coigach. The image was my attempt at creating an intricate, detailed and unique composition at what is a relative 'classic'  - as far as mountain photography in Scotland is concerned, at least! Hopefully, you agree that I have achieved that.

Name: Franka Gabler
Bio: The first kiss of morning light reaches the tree tops in Yosemite Valley. A veil of meadow mist drifts gently through the meadow, wrapping the trees in silence.
Title: First Light & Meadow Mist, Yosemite Valley
Caption: The first kiss of morning light reaches the tree tops in Yosemite Valley. A veil of meadow mist drifts gently through the meadow, wrapping the trees in silence.

Name: Grégoire Pansu
Bio: I captured this image in northern Tenerife, at a location I had long hoped to revisit after a first attempt years before, when conditions weren’t ideal. This time, the clouds parted at just the right moment—only for a few fleeting minutes—allowing me to frame the sharp cliffs through the stems of a solitary cardón cactus.
Title: Golden shores
Caption: I captured this image in northern Tenerife, at a location I had long hoped to revisit after a first attempt years before, when conditions weren’t ideal. This time, the clouds parted at just the right moment—only for a few fleeting minutes—allowing me to frame the sharp cliffs through the stems of a solitary cardón cactus.

Name: Grégoire Pansu
Bio: The small corollas clinging to the flower stems reminded me of jewels, so delicate and colorful, displaying shades ranging from pure white to deep purple. I particularly loved the composition as these well aligned floral stems echo the pointed peaks in the background, creating harmony between the foreground and the horizon.
Title: Towers of Jewels
Caption: The small corollas clinging to the flower stems reminded me of jewels, so delicate and colorful, displaying shades ranging from pure white to deep purple. I particularly loved the composition as these well aligned floral stems echo the pointed peaks in the background, creating harmony between the foreground and the horizon.

Filename: MAIN CATEGORIES/Grand Landscape/2 Runner Up-Samuel Markham-8912_55553_2198.jpg
Name: Samuel Markham
Bio: Taken deep within the wilderness of Tasmania's Southwest National Park (Australia). The sun broke through thick clouds for a brief moment illuminating the vast rugged landscape.
Title: Gateway To God
Caption: Taken deep within the wilderness of Tasmania's Southwest National Park (Australia). The sun broke through thick clouds for a brief moment illuminating the vast rugged landscape.

Filename: MAIN CATEGORIES/Grand Landscape/4 Highly Commended-Joshua Cripps-2501_58913_1052.jpg
Name: Joshua Cripps
Bio: I took this photo while flying over New Zealand's Fiordland National Park, one of the most spectacular landscapes on Earth. I shot it in hazy, late afternoon light, the layers of the fjords stretching off toward the horizon. As our plane flew over the top of this ridge, I saw this gorgeous lake nestled in the top of the mountains and couldn't press the shutter button fast enough.
Title: Hidden Gem
Caption: I took this photo while flying over New Zealand's Fiordland National Park, one of the most spectacular landscapes on Earth. I shot it in hazy, late afternoon light, the layers of the fjords stretching off toward the horizon. As our plane flew over the top of this ridge, I saw this gorgeous lake nestled in the top of the mountains and couldn't press the shutter button fast enough.

Name: Lukáš Veselý
Bio: This is the one of the most majestic places in Lofoten/Norway, but luckily it is not direct by the road so hardly anyone knows it. If I ever go to Lofoten again, it will be for laces like this.
Title: Granite scene
Caption: This is the one of the most majestic places in Lofoten/Norway, but luckily it is not direct by the road so hardly anyone knows it. If I ever go to Lofoten again, it will be for laces like this.

Name: Lukáš Veselý
Bio: This is the most majestic places in Lofoten, Norway but it is not right by the road so hardly anyone knows it.
Title: Granite scenes
Caption: This is the most majestic places in Lofoten, Norway but it is not right by the road so hardly anyone knows it.

Filename: MAIN CATEGORIES/Intimate Landscape/3 Third Place-Jude Dizon-1281_62740_1821.jpg
Name: Jude Dizon
Bio: A simple image with passing time represented by the mist. Time, much like mist, is unstoppable.
Title: Passing
Caption: A simple image with passing time represented by the mist. Time, much like mist, is unstoppable.

Filename: SPECIALS/Rocks and Geology/2 Runner Up-Doug Hammer-8492_55742_2948.jpg
Name: Doug Hammer
Bio: Exploring the reflected light and shadow on the unique patterns of the soft clay walls, Doug beautifully displays the wonder of this gorge. Sadly, he passed away in July 2025 before learning of the contest results. He would have been incredibly honored to know his work was included with this year's winners.
Title: Cathedral Gorge State Park
Caption: Exploring the reflected light and shadow on the unique patterns of the soft clay walls, Doug beautifully displays the wonder of this gorge. Sadly, he passed away in July 2025 before learning of the contest results. He would have been incredibly honored to know his work was included with this year's winners.

Name: Philipp Jakesch
Bio: I had to stop the car—the landscape was just too incredible to pass up. The soft, wet snow in the foreground made for a challenging shot, but I loved carefully lining up the beautiful, branching puddle with the famous Icelandic landmark far in the distance.
Title: On a quiet winter morning
Caption: I had to stop the car—the landscape was just too incredible to pass up. The soft, wet snow in the foreground made for a challenging shot, but I loved carefully lining up the beautiful, branching puddle with the famous Icelandic landmark far in the distance.

Filename: PHOTOGRAPHER OF THE YEAR/3 Third Place - Matt Jackisch/3-Matt Jackisch-076_53924_670.jpg
Name: Matt Jackisch
Bio: Peru is home to some of the most beautiful and photogenic mountains on the planet. In 2024, I hired a mountain guide, took a climbing course, and got as high as I could to become more intimately acquainted with these peaks. Here are the results.
Title: Mountains of Peru
Caption: Peru is home to some of the most beautiful and photogenic mountains on the planet. In 2024, I hired a mountain guide, took a climbing course, and got as high as I could to become more intimately acquainted with these peaks. Here are the results.

Filename: MAIN CATEGORIES/Intimate Landscape/4 Highly Commended-Roger Kristiansen-9781_62732_1879.jpg
Name: Roger Kristiansen
Bio: Captured just outside my doorstep on a foggy autumn morning in 2024, this image reflects the subtle beauty of local landscapes. It’s a reminder that inspiration often lies in the places closest to us.
Title: Driftwood silence – Where branches rest in fog and reflection
Caption: Captured just outside my doorstep on a foggy autumn morning in 2024, this image reflects the subtle beauty of local landscapes. It’s a reminder that inspiration often lies in the places closest to us.

Filename: MAIN CATEGORIES/Intimate Landscape/4 Highly Commended-Roger Kristiansen-9781_62732_1879.jpg
Name: Lukas Furlan
Bio: After battling stormy days in the Italian Alps, the clouds parted for a few breathtaking moments at sunset. This fiery light is what I held onto through the cold night in an unheated mountain shelter.
Title: Alpine Ember
Caption: After battling stormy days in the Italian Alps, the clouds parted for a few breathtaking moments at sunset. This fiery light is what I held onto through the cold night in an unheated mountain shelter.

Name: Andrew Lazzarini
Bio: This morning, all of nature has become a fairytale. Over everything hovers the suspended atmosphere of those frozen tears
Title: Frozen Tears
Caption: This morning, all of nature has become a fairytale. Over everything hovers the suspended atmosphere of those frozen tears

Name: Matt Jackisch
Bio: When I reached the top of the mountain, I looked down and could see it's shadow cast onto the clouds below me. At the top of the shadow was my tiny projection, surrounded by a ring of light known as a 'glory halo'. I knew this was an incredibly rare optical phenomena and tried to incorporate the larger scene into my camera to convey the magic of what I witnessed.
Title: Apex Experience
Caption: When I reached the top of the mountain, I looked down and could see it's shadow cast onto the clouds below me. At the top of the shadow was my tiny projection, surrounded by a ring of light known as a 'glory halo'. I knew this was an incredibly rare optical phenomena and tried to incorporate the larger scene into my camera to convey the magic of what I witnessed.

Name: Ian Callaghan
Bio: Ancient tree ferns stand tall while light and fog intertwine, casting a dramatic winter glow across this Black Spur gully in the Yarra Ranges, on Wurundjeri Country. The scene is a glimpse back through time, into a living landscape that has endured, unchanged in its essence, for millions of years.
Title: Gondwana
Caption: Ancient tree ferns stand tall while light and fog intertwine, casting a dramatic winter glow across this Black Spur gully in the Yarra Ranges, on Wurundjeri Country. The scene is a glimpse back through time, into a living landscape that has endured, unchanged in its essence, for millions of years.

Name: Tomasz Niedźwiedź
Bio: Traveling through a forest by train has something special about it. The landscape zooms past the window too fast for the eye to capture intricate detail. Instead, our brains register afterimages, momentary, sharp glimpses of one tree or another, depending on where we happen to subconsciously focus our sight. The rest is pure motion. Trying to capture this feeling in a photograph is a great way to kill time during a long journey. Shot in monochrome, to prevent colours from becoming a distraction, which gave the whole scene the feel of a rough sketch made with charcoal.
Title: Charcoal
Caption: Traveling through a forest by train has something special about it. The landscape zooms past the window too fast for the eye to capture intricate detail. Instead, our brains register afterimages, momentary, sharp glimpses of one tree or another, depending on where we happen to subconsciously focus our sight. The rest is pure motion. Trying to capture this feeling in a photograph is a great way to kill time during a long journey. Shot in monochrome, to prevent colours from becoming a distraction, which gave the whole scene the feel of a rough sketch made with charcoal.

Name: Chris Bryant
Bio: On a hike over Sugar Loaf (Mynydd Pen-y-fâl), Wales, in poor conditions with persistent rain and mist. Lower on the hill I took a shortcut through this old twisted wood, as It was so miserable I kept my camera in my backpack and used my iPhone.
Title: Dank Wood, Sugar Loaf, Wales.
Caption: On a hike over Sugar Loaf (Mynydd Pen-y-fâl), Wales, in poor conditions with persistent rain and mist. Lower on the hill I took a shortcut through this old twisted wood, as It was so miserable I kept my camera in my backpack and used my iPhone.

Filename: MAIN CATEGORIES/Intimate Landscape/4 Highly Commended-Roger Kristiansen-9781_62732_1879.jpg
Name: Roger Kristiansen
Bio: This photograph was taken near my home on a misty autumn morning in 2024. The still water and drifting branches capture the quiet poetry of nature close to everyday life.
Title: Driftwood silence – Where branches rest in fog and reflection
Caption: This photograph was taken near my home on a misty autumn morning in 2024. The still water and drifting branches capture the quiet poetry of nature close to everyday life.

Name: John Meragias
Bio: Taken from an open door helicopter, this photo shows two trees alone in a dry and desolate landscape. These trees have actually been dead for hundreds of years and have been permanently frozen in time together.
Title: Alone Together
Caption: Taken from an open door helicopter, this photo shows two trees alone in a dry and desolate landscape. These trees have actually been dead for hundreds of years and have been permanently frozen in time together.

Name: Jason Pettit
Bio: The winter holds an opportunity that other seasons do not. In the frozen landscape, otherwise inaccessible locations become available for exploration when the open water and marshes freeze over. New vantage points give familiar locations a whole new creative dimension to play with when you step out onto the solid waters.
Title: Small World
Caption: The winter holds an opportunity that other seasons do not. In the frozen landscape, otherwise inaccessible locations become available for exploration when the open water and marshes freeze over. New vantage points give familiar locations a whole new creative dimension to play with when you step out onto the solid waters.

Name: Marlin Mills
Bio: In 2020, the Bush Wildfire destroyed 193,455 acres (78,288 ha) of the Tonto National Forest, in the Sonora Desert northeast of Phoenix. Hundreds of people drive through this region, daily, witnessing a landscape marred by burn scars from that wildfire. This image of a burned, decades old, saguaro cactus, a cactus only found in the Sonora Desert, highlights the destruction that occurred in this region.
Title: The Standing Dead
Caption: In 2020, the Bush Wildfire destroyed 193,455 acres (78,288 ha) of the Tonto National Forest, in the Sonora Desert northeast of Phoenix. Hundreds of people drive through this region, daily, witnessing a landscape marred by burn scars from that wildfire. This image of a burned, decades old, saguaro cactus, a cactus only found in the Sonora Desert, highlights the destruction that occurred in this region.

Name: Dylan Nardini
Bio: A large bogey expanse, peppered with wild cotton grass, creates an open air stage for this band of Caledonian Pines, that stand majestically and with attitude in the early morning mist. Found in a quiet patch of South Lanarkshire, Scotland.
Title: The Frontman - South Lanarkshire, Scotland.
Caption: A large bogey expanse, peppered with wild cotton grass, creates an open air stage for this band of Caledonian Pines, that stand majestically and with attitude in the early morning mist. Found in a quiet patch of South Lanarkshire, Scotland.

Name: Rick Bowden
Bio: This image was taken near Bintree Mill in the Wensum Valley, Norfolk, on a clod and foggy January morning. The area is often frequented by photographers who mainly come to shoot the water mill itself, but on this occasion I decided to concentrate on this little scene by the river. The fog was giving just enough separation between the trees and the water was still enough to give the perfect reflection. I've been back to this spot many times since but I never had conditions as amazing as these.
Title: Timeless. A foggy morning in the serenity of the Wensum Valley.
Caption: This image was taken near Bintree Mill in the Wensum Valley, Norfolk, on a clod and foggy January morning. The area is often frequented by photographers who mainly come to shoot the water mill itself, but on this occasion I decided to concentrate on this little scene by the river. The fog was giving just enough separation between the trees and the water was still enough to give the perfect reflection. I've been back to this spot many times since but I never had conditions as amazing as these.

Name: Paul Hoelen
Bio: Ancient ice, broken free from its glacier, drifts quietly across Jökulsárlón Lagoon, its layered curves revealed in a moment of stillness before continuing its journey to the sea. The photograph offers a meditation on impermanence—a passage from mountain source to ocean, a fleeting pause before dissolving into saltwater, under the transient dance of seabirds wheeling overhead.
Title: Glacial Curves. Jökulsárlón Lagoon, Iceland.
Caption: Ancient ice, broken free from its glacier, drifts quietly across Jökulsárlón Lagoon, its layered curves revealed in a moment of stillness before continuing its journey to the sea. The photograph offers a meditation on impermanence—a passage from mountain source to ocean, a fleeting pause before dissolving into saltwater, under the transient dance of seabirds wheeling overhead.
